Authors:
Miriam Marzall-Pereira, Daiani Cristina Savi, Lisandra
Ferreira-Maba, Paloma Gerlach Ribas, Vanessa Kava
Title:
Revealing the prevalence of Neopestalotiopsis,
Pseudopestalotiopsis, and Pestalotiopsis in Brazilian biomes
Keywords:
Amazon Rainforest - Atlantic Forest  Biodiversity 
Caatinga - Celastraceae  Cerrado  New species - Pampa  Pantanal 
Phylogeny - Taxonomy
Abstract:
Brazil is known for its massive biodiversity, holding in
its territory between 15 and 20 % of the total number of species
described on the planet. Brazilian biomes vary from forests,
savanna-like vegetations, to wetlands and this multiplicity performs a
great influence to label Brazil as a megadiverse country. An incredible
number of fungi from plants, sea, and soil are described every year and
among this variety, the Pestalotiopsis group is attention-grabbing.
Pestalotiopsis strains have shown potential for biotechnological
applications given its secondary metabolites and enzymes production;
moreover, some species in the genus causes diseases in several plants.
The Pestalotiopsis genus was recently divided into three genera based on
phylogenetic and morphological analyses, namely Pestalotiopsis,
Neopestalotiopsis, and Pseudopestalotiopsis. However, these pestalotiod
genera are often misidentified as Pestalotiopsis and the prevalence of
the three genera in Brazil is still uncertain. This study aimed to
establish an overview of Pestalotiopsis, Neopestalotiopsis, and
Pseudopestalotiopsis strains isolated in Brazilian Biomes. We evaluated
the genetic information of so-called ‘Pestalotiopsis’ strains in Brazil
based on searches in PubMed and GenBank databases. After analyzing 165
sequences and 38 studies, we observed 102 Neopestalotiopsis, 49
Pestalotiopsis, and 10 Pseudopestalotiopsis isolates, distributed in all
Brazilian biomes: Amazonian and Atlantic forests, Caatinga, Cerrado,
Pampa, and Pantanal. Among the 165 isolates, 63 had inaccurate
identification at the genus level. Some of this misidentification was
observed in studies published before the reclassification and the
introduction of the new genera, but some of them happened in recent
studies and four of those isolates represent a very distinct genus,
Eutypella. The limited information about the prevalence of the
Pestalotiopsis, Neopestalotiopsis, and Pseudopestalotiopsis in Brazil is
also evidence that novel species are probably being neglected. For this
reason, we identified at species level some Neopestalotiopsis isolates
from the Atlantic Forest, isolated from asymptomatic leaves of Maytenus
ilicifolia (Celastraceae). Those endophytic isolates were subjected to
morphological and phylogenetic analysis of ITS, TUB, and EF-1a sequences
which led to the description of two new species Neopestalotiopsis
celastracearum and Neopestalotiopsis azevedoi from South Brazil. Our
data concerning the prevalence of pestalotiod with different lifestyles
in Brazilian Biomes reinforce the importance of Brazil as a repository
of species diversity and a vast reservoir for biotechnological
discovery.
